text: Windows 10 included split-screening

and window-snapping by
dragging applications
into edges of the screen,

allowing users to create
multi-window layouts on the fly.

That functionality still
exists in Windows 11,

along with a newer system
called snap layouts
that works without dragging.
To check if snap layouts are active,

open the settings menu and
click on the system category.
Next, select "Multitasking."

Snap windows will appear
as one of the options.
Make sure its toggle is switched to on.

Hovering over the maximize
button on a window
will reveal the snap layouts options.
There are several options for the layout
and quantity of windows displayed,
allowing users to display two,
three, or four applications at once.

For instance, selecting
the two-panel option
and clicking the right half

will snap the current
window to the right side

and fill the left side
with other open windows.
Click one to have it fill that space.

Similarly, selecting a
three- or four-panel layout
will put your current window
into the space you initially select

and prompt you to choose
other active windows
to fill the remaining spots.
And as with Windows 10,
you can still drag and rearrange
windowed applications manually

by clicking and holding
the menu bar on them
and moving to the desired position.
